Pillar: HIPAA & Data Privacy

Pillar: HIPAA & Data Privacy

1.0 Strategic Mandate

As a life and health agency, you are a "Covered Entity" (or a "Business Associate" of one) under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). This is not optional.

Any information that can identify a client in relation to their health status, applications, or policy information is Protected Health Information (PHI). This includes names, dates, policy numbers, and any health-related data collected during underwriting.

A data breach or improper handling of PHI leads to severe fines and a complete loss of client and carrier trust. The entire technology stack must be "HIPAA-compliant" by default.

2.0 Operational Mandates (Non-Negotiable)

Requirement Standard Operating Procedure (SOP)
1. HIPAA-Compliant Storage SOP: All client-facing documents (applications, needs analyses, consent forms) and all call/meeting recordings must be stored on HIPAA-compliant platforms. <br> Action: This means using a HIPAA-compliant CRM, cloud storage (e.g., Google Workspace w/ BAA), and recording solution. You must have a signed Business Associate Agreement (BAA) with every technology vendor that "touches" PHI.
2. Secure Communications SOP: PHI must not be sent over non-secure channels. <br> Prohibited: Sending applications, underwriting notes, or client lists via standard email, text message, or non-secure messaging apps (e.g., standard WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger). <br> Mandatory: Use secure, encrypted email portals, a HIPAA-compliant CRM portal, or secure fax to transmit PHI.
3. Access & Device Control SOP: All agents and staff must use secure, unique passwords and Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) on all systems. <br> Action: All devices (laptops, phones) used to access PHI must be password-protected and have remote-wipe capability enabled in case of loss or theft.
4. "Need to Know" Principle SOP: Agents and staff should only have access to the minimum PHI necessary to perform their jobs. <Access to the full database should be restricted to compliance officers and senior leadership.
5. Data Destruction SOP: When a client relationship is terminated (and after the 10-year CMS retention period), their data must be securely and permanently destroyed, not just deleted.
